22fad953-37e4-4245-9dcf-eb293e365d97.description: Genazzano Institute presents 'The Learning Blueprint.' This course by LME Global is a practical metacognition course designed specifically for students. Created and taught by neuroscientist and educator, Dr. Jared Cooney Horvath, this interactive course reveals the fundamental truths (and exposes the common myths) concerning how our brains actually work. More importantly, it teaches students how they can adapt these realities to expand their learning power and boost their academic performance.
22fad953-37e4-4245-9dcf-eb293e365d97.name: The Learning Blueprint

alignments.name: Australian Curriculum: General Capabilities
alignments.description: This badge aligns with standards from the Australian Curriculum - General Capabilities: Personal and Social; Critical and Creative Thinking.

badge_template_activities.title: COURSE: Students participate in a formal course delivered live and supported by videos and reading material.  Students learn about topics including: Brain parts and function; Neuroplasticity; Memory Encoding, Storage and Access; Learning, Emotions and Stress; Study; Sleep; Genetics; Intelligence, Time Management and Wellbeing.

JOURNAL: Students are supported by material from a companion workbook. They are required to create an online journal entry for each lesson, where they answer questions, reflect on themes and consider applications of the learning to their life and study. The journal is submitted as part of the microcredential requirements.

ASSESSMENT: Students complete an online quiz testing them about their understanding of the content delivered in this program. Students also complete a reflection activity on practical applications of the learning from this course.

757c1f62-51b3-41e5-95f0-8906a87cae86.description: The microcredential 'Foundations in Philanthropy' was developed by Genazzano Institute in partnership with The Sisterhood of St Vincent's Foundation. Badge Earners participate in a range of learning experiences to develop an understanding of the concept of 'giving' and the variety of ways that people can contribute time, skills, goods and funds to make a meaningful impact for others. A practical project builds skills and knowledge in developing awareness and fundraising campaigns.
757c1f62-51b3-41e5-95f0-8906a87cae86.name: Foundations in Philanthopy

alignments.name: Australian Curriculum: General Capabilities
alignments.description: This badge aligns with standards from the Australian Curriculum - General Capabilities: Critical and Creative Thinking; Ethical Understanding.

badge_template_activities.title: Students participate in a range of educational presentations led by the St Vincent's Foundation and The Sisterhood of St Vincent's.  The learning covers the need for support by 'giving' through the lens of the hospital, including: history of the hospital; healthcare and research and the work of St Vincent's foundation.  'The Sisterhood' is highlighted as an example of the founder's philanthropic efforts to promote women in health and science and to support the hospital in a meaningful way

Students learn about how people use events and campaigns to promote donations, awareness, volunteering and sharing of expertise.  The learning provides examples of a range of different campaigns and highlights key elements of putting together a successful philanthropic campaign or event.
Students work in groups to design a philanthropic campaign or event using key criteria. Students produce suitable marketing material to promote the event.
Student work is submitted in a digital media format and assessed according to criteria. Students complete a quiz and reflection on learning & skill development to earn the microcredential.
St Vincent's Foundation

60ead96d-2114-43a1-8ada-2e3e602e2bef.description: Genazzano's 'The EDGE' program aims to encourage students to get comfortable with the journey of embracing discomfort, and living on ‘the edge’. Throughout the year students will be pushed outside their comfort zones in an array of different environments. To successfully obtain their microcredential, students will be required to demonstrate skills of teamwork, leadership, confidence and resilience in addition to completing a reflection on how they developed the focus skill in each unit.

badge_template_activities.title: ROCK CLIMBING. Focus Skill: Teamwork Students will be required to display teamwork in a variety of skills throughout each double lesson. Communication, encouragement and concentration will be vital in ensuring peers can support each other climbing. A willingness to work with a variety of classmates will be vital in successfully displaying this skill.

The EDGE SEPEP NETBALL. Focus Skill: Leadership.  Students will take a leadership role in the development of the Netball program. Students will take control of their own learning experiences. Students will work together to fulfill a number of roles including, coach, umpire, team manager, scorer. Students will be required to display leadership and organization skills, fulfilling their role to enable their team to complete all tasks.

The EDGE GYMNASTICS. Focus Skill: Confidence. Throughout this unit students will participate in activities on a variety of Gymnastics apparatus. At the culmination of the unit students will be required to perform one new skill that they have learnt on an apparatus of their choice in front of their peers.

The EDGE BRONZE MEDALLION. Focus Skill: Resilience.  Throughout this unit students will perform a variety of water safety skills and activities. Some of these activities may challenge students, which is where the greatest learning occurs. Students will need to continue to work through all activities, attempting to complete all set tasks to the best of their ability, students are asked to continue to attempt skills even if at first they did not succeed.

Reflection: Students will be required to complete a reflection on each unit. The reflection will be completed on their Learning profile page. Students’ attendance may impact their ability to obtain their microcredential.

e98bd3ff-d266-458f-8fc0-5a23bec9c213.description: This course, created by industry professionals SLV Productions, is designed to equip learners with fundamental skills to manage technical aspects of stage productions in the areas of stage management, audio production and lighting. The course will be delivered live by SLV Productions, supported by Performing Arts teachers, and will include theory, practical demonstrations and experience and assessment.

badge_template_activities.title: LIGHTING 1 Introduction: This course provides learners with an overview of lighting theory including: fixtures, lens angles, accessories and health and safety. The practical component will be delivered separately and learners will have the opportunity to experiment with fixtures and to learn how to create different intensities and effects. Practical aspects of health and safety are explored here.

LIGHTING 2 & 3: Design Process & Lighting Desk: Learners are taught about communication with the production Director, managing budgets, rehearsals, creating synopsis and lighting plots, technical rehearsals, dress rehearsals and health and safety considerations. The practical component of the learning includes operating the lighting desk, operating a plotted show, using a followspot and lighting control principles.
Each learner will plot 8 cues for a song from a musical.

STAGE MANAGEMENT 1 & 2: Learners are introduced to the role of the stage manager in professional theatre and what the role entails for school productions. Key areas of focus are: script marking, calling cues, professional prompt scripts, stage managers desk set up, backstage pager, monitoring a show from full view and stage marking. Health and Safety considerations are reviewed from stage management perspective.
Learners mark a script and practice calling cues. Learners use a professional prompt script to practice calling 30 cues for one song from a musical.

AUDIO 1& 2: Introduction to QLab. These sessions are focussed on using QLab and to operate a sound desk. Key areas of focus are importing audio, fade in/out, sound levels, file management, sound desk set up and operation and signal flow, microphone technology (including placement and map reading), marking the script and tuning speakers.
Demonstrating sound desk operation and using FX such as reverb and delay.

Learners are required to participate in practical skills demonstrations as described above. Knowledge will be assessed with tests on aspects of lighting, stage management and sound production with the assessor evaluating skills and tests.

a2c19a90-88ac-4357-bc35-6d203a05510d.description: Students will learn how to use 3D modelling software to create a range of products to be used for classroom learning and personal use. The aim of the course is to facilitate a program to teach teachers how they can use this technology in their learning and teaching program. Participants keep a journal of notes and record a design process which could be used to model student learning outcomes.
a2c19a90-88ac-4357-bc35-6d203a05510d.name: Making: 3d Modelling and 3d Printing Short Course

Participants maintain a folio throughout the course, with notes and record of their design process and generation of work.

810682cc-25cb-4fc9-a9f3-8a0dffaf1f6a.description: AFL Umpiring & Genazzano development program to build skills in: umpiring techniques, knowledge of AFL rules, decision making, effective communication, leadership, confidence and resilience.
810682cc-25cb-4fc9-a9f3-8a0dffaf1f6a.name: Genazzano AFL Umpiring

badge_template_activities.title: Students will participate in weekly sessions led by Genazzano and AFL Umpiring staff to learn game rules, decision making skills, umpiring techniques, effective communication, leadership, confidence and resilience.

Leadership: Participant is required to display positive leadership qualities throughout the umpiring unit e.g. display positive teamwork skills (supporting peers through encouragement and feedback); listen attentively to coaches, ensuring they understand and execute required skills. Participants are required to demonstrate the ability to deliver clear and concise communication when umpiring.

Confidence: Participant displays confidence when performing in front of coaches and peers. E.g. Participates in all discipline activities (field, boundary, and goal umpiring); makes calls and decisions as required and effectively executes skills, communicating clearly and confidently.

Resilience: Participant builds resilience and learning growth throughout umpiring unit E.g. making attempts to call the correct decisions in different scenarios, even if signal decisions are wrong. The participant listens to external feedback provided by coaches and attempts to apply feedback to their performance.

Communication: Participant demonstrates positive and effective communication skills throughout the umpiring unit E.g. making attempts to communicate calmly in different on/off field scenarios, even if signal decisions are wrong.

Reflection journal: After each session participants will record what they’ve learnt and what they found most challenging about the different umpiring disciplines. The final reflection is an overview of what was taught in the program and how effectively it was displayed on football field for the half time AFL Experience. Observation & feedback: Participants' skills development in leadership, communication, umpiring techniques and applying feedback will be observed by program leaders.
AFL half-time umpiring experience (2 hours optional). Participants have the opportunity to practise skills during an AFL game.

c5e0ee13-5ef2-43ff-9c7b-0c9c5ae6c0c9.description: Counterpoint literally means ‘point-against-point.’ In music it translates as simply ‘note-against-note.’ This Micro-credential aims to guide students through an introduction to the basic rules of writing melodies through a five-stage sequence known as SPECIES COUNTERPOINT.
c5e0ee13-5ef2-43ff-9c7b-0c9c5ae6c0c9.name: Music Composition: Species Counterpoint - Ceating Polyphony

alignments.name: Australian Curriculum: General Capabilities
alignments.description: This badge aligns with standards from the Australian Curriculum - General Capabilities: Personal and Social; Critical and Creative Thinking.

badge_template_activities.title: The development of skills demonstrated through works of counterpoint in weekly classes is a key aspect of the course. Students will be required to write and submit set pieces demonstrating the application techniques developed through the program. Students will learn the contrapuntal rules of each stage via weekly classes. Students progress through each stage with the consolidation of weekly set tasks over the course of 10-15 weeks.

Students completing this program will learn contrapuntal rules and apply these to set melodies known as a Cantus Firmus. They will also learn concepts of consonance and dissonance in the production of polyphony [many sounds]. These fundamentals of music have been applied by composers from the late 12th century through to the present day.
Students will produce original works of 5th Species Counterpoint that will be assessed by the course convenor.
A selection of the student works on 5th Species Counterpoint will be performed by an associate artist for an audience.

631da5d0-f871-415a-ab64-15d1f6254bcd.description: The nextGen Pathways: Professional Folio & Experience badge is awarded to learners who create a digital professional folio and participate in a formal program of Work Experience.
631da5d0-f871-415a-ab64-15d1f6254bcd.name: nextGEN Pathways: Professional Folio & Work Experience

badge_template_activities.title: INDUSTRY EXPERIENCE: Formal Work experience. Learners will identify a career/industry of interest. The program requirements are that learners undertake a minimum of 5 days Work Experience in a work place setting, overseen by a supervisor at the work place. Learners are required to document their experience and reflect on their future career planning. A workplace report should be provided by the employer to the College.

PROFESSIONAL FOLIO: Learners will develop a professional folio which will serve as a digital CV for applications for employment, education and other programs. The portfolio will showcase the learner's achievements including: education, employment. volunteer work, skills, experiences, leadership, references, courses and micro credentials.

0420d63e-3ba1-4d87-96a5-be0f489863c5.description: The GenEncounter Award of Endeavour is designed to nurture, strengthen and build the ability of each participant to: understand and manage their emotions; develop their sense of self; promote personal agency and build resilience in the face of difficulty, challenge or adversity. Participants are required to determine a personal growth challenge and to cycle through actions and reflective practices to explore, inform and build self-knowledge, skills and confidence.
0420d63e-3ba1-4d87-96a5-be0f489863c5.name: GenEncounter: Award of Endeavour

badge_template_activities.title: Participants reflect upon personal development and community engagement and design and deliver a project with the aim of growth and learning. Theme examples include: Improve connection with peers; Acceptance into the community; Protection of the environment; Promoting Philanthropy; Innovation for a more inclusive society & Encouraging respectful relationships. A substantial project to address a core question and key criteria is developed and undertaken under the guidance of a mentor.

Participants create a folio of evidence that: details the reflective project question; describes in detail the project including processes and activities and provides evidence of the key criteria. This evidence may be in the form of a range of mediums including: text, surveys, video, PowerPoint, photographs, audio, testimonials, project work, other etc.

Participants submit evidence to demonstrate a project response to the research question and each criteria in the form of a portfolio. The mentor will determine if the evidence for each criteria is met and will refer the candidate's submission to the Level Coordinator for verification. Participants whose projects are deemed by 2 assessors to fulfil all criteria will be referred to receive the Award.

af6498e1-a568-4269-bbf7-8cb629d407f5.description: The Visual Arts Technician Internship, offered through the Gen Art Academie is a course created by Visual Arts educator, author, faculty head and Director of the Gen Art Academie, Mrs Joanne Saville. It is delivered through the Visual Arts Faculty, and is designed specifically for student graduates who have an interest in the visual arts and studio practices. Interns develop key professional and technical skills related to supporting the running of an art department and creation of art works.
af6498e1-a568-4269-bbf7-8cb629d407f5.name: Internship - Visual Arts Technician

alignments.name: Australian National Microcredentials Framework
alignments.description: This Internship is designed to meet the requirements of the National Microcredentials Framework.

badge_template_activities.title: To be awarded the Visual Art Technician Internship, the applicant must submit an application and participate in the interview process. Only one Visual Art internship will be offered each year and will go to to successful applicant in a competitive process led by the Director of the Gen Art Academie. The Internship is open to a candidate (post Year 12) who has a background in visual arts and/or is studying in a field related to visual art.

The Professional experience requires the applicant to attend the workplace at the scheduled times and undertake the work outlined in the job description and engage in the department activities as required. The internship is overseen by the Director of Gen Academie/ Faculty leader who will review the intern's progress, output and skill development and will provide verbal feedback and guidance on a fortnightly basis.

Internship activities and skills development: The intern will provide classroom support; develop technical expertise in areas such as framing; 3D/ inkjet printing; laser cutting & ceramic firing; will manage stock control, ordering & purchasing and will curate and display artworks.

Semester Review: The intern's development and performance will monitored by observation and will be supported and with feedback & guidance. The intern is required to perform technical skills at a professional standard, including following of safety protocols. Displays and exhibitions will be of a high quality, as verified by the Director/Faculty Head. Interns will produce a written evaluation and reflection each semester along with photographic evidence of their work.

3f7d90a6-85da-440f-867e-2d81604a6f52.description: Counterpoint literally means ‘point-against-point.’ In music it translates as simply ‘note-against-note.’ Via weekly classes, students will learn to create Rounds and then Canons and ultimately, Two Part Inventions. Students progress through each stage with the consolidation of weekly set tasks. This this Micro-credential aims to extend who have completed the SPECIES COUNTERPOINT course. Selections of the student' s completed works will performed on piano by an associate artist.

badge_template_activities.title: Students completing this program will learn the structures and contrapuntal rules of IMITATIVE COUNTERPOINT including Rounds, Canon and Two Part Invention.

The development of skills demonstrated through works of counterpoint in weekly classes is a key aspect of the course. Students will be required to write and submit set pieces demonstrating the application techniques developed through the program which will be assessed by the convenor.
A selection of the student works on Imitative Counterpoint (Two part Inventions) will be performed by an associate artist for an audience.

de3af640-ecc2-4795-a0ad-041e839248c3.description: Music composition comprises many aspects and comes in many forms, styles and genres. Yet, no matter what form it may be in, it is ultimately about organizing sound. This microcredential aims to guide students through a variety of approaches to notated composition with score-based software. Students will be encouraged to compose for small ‘live’ chamber ensembles.
de3af640-ecc2-4795-a0ad-041e839248c3.name: Music Composition: Notation - Creating Music for Live Performances

badge_template_activities.title: • This course will provide exposure to a wide variety of approaches to Composition. Key focus areas include: • NOTATION - conventions, literacy and clarity; SCORE PRODUCTION - extractions, management; COUNTERPOINT & HARMONY – Contrapuntal fundamentals, 7th & 9th chord vocabulary; ORCHESTRATION & ARRANGEMENT - Transposing instruments and Instrument family groupings.

• The development of skills demonstrated through works of composition in weekly classes is a key aspect of the course. Students will be required to write and submit score-based pieces demonstrating the application techniques developed through the program. Frameworks for composition tasks will be set in discussion the teacher.

• Students completing this program will gain professional experience through having their works performed in a formal setting. It is an expectation that at least one work will be given a ‘live’ chamber group performance or theatre performance.

de1b8957-7a43-4156-b3a9-6ffe1292d60d.description: The Podcast Production badge is awarded to participants who have demonstrated skills in the various elements required to create a podcast and have produced a finished episode.

badge_template_activities.title: PROJECT PLANNING: The podcast planning requires the participant to identify the theme, format and intended audience for the podcast. This aspect requires research into elements that are needed for a podcast such as: sourcing music; writing an intro; podcast art design; hosting platforms; writing interview questions; developing interviewing techniques; introducing topics etc.

COURSE: The course will cover technical aspects such as skills and tips for recording and saving audio files; using the podcast platform; interviewing techniques; setting up interviews; creating a podcast identity using music, sound and art; audio file editing and promotion.
PORTFOLIO: The outcome will be submission of a finished product: a recorded and edited podcast episode including Title; Intro; Content; Outro.
POST-PROGRAM – Students submit a short written analysis and reflection on the process articulating their learning, challenges and outcomes.

3d7a9041-178b-46d9-bb2d-fa9babc57033.description: Applied Computing Fundamentals promotes the basic concepts in computer science, cyber security and networking. Students engage in a series of online modules powered by Grok, The Australian Computing Academy, IBM and CISCO that challenge them to build basic Python programming, cyber security, and digital fundamentals for the workforce. This micro credential aims to prepare students for VCE Applied Computing or ignite their interest further in this vital area of digital technologies.
3d7a9041-178b-46d9-bb2d-fa9babc57033.name: Applied Computing Fundamentals

badge_template_activities.title: Python has been widely recognised as one of the world’s most popular and versatile programming languages. Students complete 3 Grok Modules (Python for Beginners, Introduction to Programming - Beginners, Introduction to Programming 2) plus use the Python Playground to create their own program, reflecting what they have learned. Students must also choose 1 competition to compete in for 2021 (NCSS Challenge or WebComp).

Cryptography - This challenge introduces basic cryptography concepts in relation to data representation and securing online communication, and how these are implemented through code. It teaches programming in the context of classic cryptographic ciphers like rotation, XOR and mixed-substitution, and explains the techniques used to break these forms of encryption.  Information, Privacy and Security -  protect yourself from hackers and maybe consider a career in cybersecurity.

CISCO Packet Tracer - Students work though the Introduction to Packet Tracer course.  It teaches basic operations of the tool with multiple hands-on activities helping you to visualize a network using everyday examples, including Internet of Things (IoT). Core Skills: Simulate data interactions traveling through a network;  Visualize the network in both logical and physical modes; Apply skills through practice, using labs and Cisco Packet Tracer activities; Critical thinking and problem-solving

IBM Skills Build -  Working in a Digital World.  Build an understanding of key skills for professional success and core soft skills needed in the IT workforce. Skills include: creating and delivering presentations; using agile approaches for working professionally to deliver quality work and experiences to customers; collaborating effectively with teams; communicating with impact; dealing with challenges in a controlled and focused manner; and solving problems and implementing solutions.

18b811d5-54e8-4bde-ab3d-2ace393a4222.description: Music composition comprises many aspects and comes in many forms, styles and genres. Yet, no matter what form it may be in, it is ultimately about organizing sound. This Microcredential aims to guide students through a variety of approaches to composition with sequencing software. Students will be encouraged to compose for soundtracks that could accompany film, multi-media productions and also live theatre performances.
18b811d5-54e8-4bde-ab3d-2ace393a4222.name: Music Composition: Sequencing - Creating Music for Theatre & Soundtracks

badge_template_activities.title: • This comprehensive course will provide exposure to a wide variety of approaches to SEQUENCING, including aspects of multiple tracks, quantization, equalization, effects and compression. The classes will also develop skills in ORCHESTRATION & ARRANGEMENT.

• The development of skills demonstrated through works of composition in weekly classes is a key aspect of the course. Students will be required to write and submit sequenced pieces demonstrating the application techniques developed through the program.

• Students completing this program will gain professional experience through having their works contribute to a soundtrack for either a short film, as multi-media production or live theatre performance. Frameworks for composition tasks will be set in discussion the teacher.
